articles.headline: Delta Posts Big Profit but Shares Fall
articles.snippet: Delta Air Lines reported its biggest quarterly profit in a decade, but investors worry that the airline industry will repeat mistakes that have hurt past recoveries.
articles.abstract: Delta Air Lines reported its biggest quarterly profit in a decade, but investors worry that the airline industry will repeat mistakes that have hurt past recoveries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines reported its biggest quarterly profit in a decade on Monday, but investors were concerned that Delta and the rest of the airline industry would repeat the mistakes that have jeopardized many past recoveries.

articles.headline: Senate Is Set to Extend Aid to the Jobless
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats are poised to break a partisan stalemate over extending benefits.
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats are poised to break a partisan stalemate over extending benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats are poised to break a partisan stalemate on Tuesday over extending unemployment benefits for millions of Americans who have been jobless for six months or more, but the fight seems certain to continue playing out as a defining issue in the midterm elections.

articles.headline: An Outspoken Man in a Secretive Trade
articles.snippet: Hugh Hendry says he thinks China’s growth is almost over and would short President Obama if he could.
articles.abstract: Hugh Hendry says he thinks China’s growth is almost over and would short President Obama if he could.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Hugh Hendry has a big mouth, as Hugh Hendry will tell you.

articles.headline: African Studies Give Women Hope in H.I.V. Fight
articles.snippet: Two new studies found different ways to sharply cut H.I.V. infections among women: a vaginal gel and a system of cash payments.
articles.abstract: Two new studies found different ways to sharply cut H.I.V. infections among women: a vaginal gel and a system of cash payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: VULINDLELA, South Africa  With an AIDS vaccine still out of reach, two rigorous new studies have found different ways to sharply cut H.I.V. infections among women and schoolgirls, who make up a majority of the newly infected in sub-Saharan Africa.

articles.headline: E-Books Top Hardcovers at Amazon
articles.snippet: Amazon sold 180 Kindle books for every 100 hardcover books in the last month.
articles.abstract: Amazon sold 180 Kindle books for every 100 hardcover books in the last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Monday was a day for the history books  if those will even exist in the future.

articles.headline: I.B.M. Moves to Concentrate Power at Top
articles.snippet: I.B.M. is reshuffling its top management one level below the chief executive, Samuel J. Palmisano, perhaps signaling that he will stay on past the age of 60.
articles.abstract: I.B.M. is reshuffling its top management one level below the chief executive, Samuel J. Palmisano, perhaps signaling that he will stay on past the age of 60.
articles.lead_paragraph: I.B.M. is reshuffling its top management one level below the chief executive, Samuel J. Palmisano, giving greater responsibility to four senior executives.

articles.headline: Need a Mortgage? Don’t Get Pregnant
articles.snippet: Cautious lenders want borrowers to be on the job with guaranteed income, not on or preparing to go on maternity or paternity leave.
articles.abstract: Cautious lenders want borrowers to be on the job with guaranteed income, not on or preparing to go on maternity or paternity leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: Expectant parents shopping for a home are not the only ones concerned about the date of the baby’s arrival.

articles.headline: Why Should Hefner Have All the Fun?
articles.snippet: A rival bid has arisen to Hugh Hefner’s effort to take Playboy Enterprises private. Should the company be allowed to ignore it to the detriment of shareholders?
articles.abstract: A rival bid has arisen to Hugh Hefner’s effort to take Playboy Enterprises private. Should the company be allowed to ignore it to the detriment of shareholders?
articles.lead_paragraph: “If I sold it, my life would be over.”

articles.headline: Iraq’s Conflict, Reflected in a Family Tragedy
articles.snippet: It reads like a short version of the war: a man who worked for the Americans was killed by his son, an insurgent.
articles.abstract: It reads like a short version of the war: a man who worked for the Americans was killed by his son, an insurgent.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAMARRA, Iraq  When the Americans arrived, Hamid Ahmad, a former air force warrant officer imprisoned under Saddam Hussein, imagined a new life for his family, freed from the burdens of tyranny. In seven hard years, nothing went as planned.

articles.headline: A City Outsources Everything. Sky Doesn’t Fall.
articles.snippet: So far, the decision by Maywood, Calif., to outsource all of its municipal work has not been disastrous.
articles.abstract: So far, the decision by Maywood, Calif., to outsource all of its municipal work has not been disastrous.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAYWOOD, Calif.  Not once, not twice, but three times in the last two weeks, Andrew Quezada says, he was stopped and questioned by the authorities here.

articles.headline: Japan Training Program Is Said to Exploit Workers
articles.snippet: A program brings thousands of apprentices to Japan, but critics say employers pay illegally low wages and treat workers poorly.
articles.abstract: A program brings thousands of apprentices to Japan, but critics say employers pay illegally low wages and treat workers poorly.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIROSHIMA, Japan  Six young Chinese women arrived in this historic city three summers ago, among the tens of thousands of apprentices brought to Japan each year on the promise of job training, good pay and a chance at a better life back home.
